summary: "The Divine Comedy" is an epic poem by Dante Alighieri, written between 1308 and 1321. It's considered the most important work in Italian literature and one of the Western world's greatest literary masterpieces. The poem is divided into three parts: Inferno (Hell), Purgatorio (Purgatory), and Paradiso (Heaven), describing Dante's journey through the afterlife. It helped establish the Tuscan language as modern Italian. The story uses medieval Catholic beliefs to show the soul's path to God, guided by famous figures like Virgil and Beatrice. Originally just called "Comedy," the "Divine" was added later to highlight its grand style and subject.
title: Divine Comedy
